(1) In the past, in the Jeak Li monastery, there was an elder bhiká¹£u who had attained arhatship. He was leading a novice monk. At that time, he came down to the city to go sightseeing. His robes and alms bowl were very heavy. He told the novice monk to carry them and followed behind him.
On the way, the novice monk had this thought:
People in the world all suffer. If one wants to avoid this suffering, what kind of path should one follow?
Having contemplated like this,
The Buddha always praises the bodhisattvas as supreme. I should now give rise to the mind of a bodhisattva.
As soon as he had this thought, his teacher, using his ability to perceive the minds of others, saw what he was thinking and said to the novice monk:
Bring your robes and alms bowl.
The novice monk took his robes and alms bowl and handed them to his teacher. The teacher said to the novice monk:
You go ahead.
As soon as the novice monk was in front, he had another thought:

The path of the bodhisattva is extremely difficult. Giving one's head when asked for one's head, giving one's eyes when asked for one's eyes, this is extremely difficult and not something I can accomplish. It is better to quickly attain arhatship and quickly escape suffering.
The teacher again knew what he was thinking and said to the novice monk:
You carry your robes and alms bowl and follow behind me.
In this way, three times. The novice monk was astonished and did not know why.
He went to the place where they were staying and with palms joined, he asked his teacher to explain the reason.
His teacher replied:
Because you have advanced three times on the path of the bodhisattva, I have also pushed you to the front three times;
Your mind has three retrogressions, therefore I push you to the back.
The reason is this: the merit of giving rise to the bodhisattva mind surpasses filling the trichiliocosm and accomplishing arhats.

(2) In the past, there was a wheel-turning sage king who first gave birth to 999 sons, all of whom were extremely handsome, intelligent, and had physical strength. Some possessed 28 marks, some possessed 30 marks, and some possessed 31 marks.

The sage king is likened to the Buddha, the eldest sons are likened to the lower two vehicles, and the youngest son is likened to the bodhisattva.

It is said that although the bodhisattva is mixed with defilements, as long as he can give rise to the great intention, he will certainly be remembered by the buddhas, and devas, nÄgas, and spirits will all give rise to respect and love for him.

This analogy illustrates that when discussing, one must wait for the meaning to come out of the mouth before debating.
If one raises objections when the meaning is still in the mouth and the principle has not yet been clearly expressed, it is like stepping on it in the mouth.

(15) Once the Buddha and his disciples entered the city of Shravasti to beg for food. On the way, they saw a ditch filled with filth and all kinds of impure things from the city. There was an old mother pig lying in the filthy ditch with her piglets.

At that time, the Buddha smiled, revealing his forty teeth and four fangs. From the four fangs, he emitted a great light that illuminated the trichiliocosm and the ten directions. The light then circled the Buddha's body three times and entered through his chest.

According to the Dharma of all Buddhas, when speaking of matters of hell, the light enters from the soles of the feet; when speaking of matters of animals, the light enters from the calves; when speaking of matters of hungry ghosts, the light enters from the thighs; when speaking of human matters, the light enters from the waist; when speaking of matters of the heavens, the light enters from the chest; when speaking of matters of the Å›rÄvakas, the light enters from the mouth; when speaking of matters of the pratyekabuddhas, the light enters from the mark between the eyebrows; when speaking of matters of all Buddhas and Bodhisattvas, the light enters from the crown of the head.
Ä€nanda saw the light enter through the chest and knew that the Buddha wished to speak of matters of the heavens. He immediately knelt for a long time and asked the Buddha to explain its meaning.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
In the past, countless eons ago, there was an elder who lacked children. He had only one daughter who was upright, extremely beautiful, intelligent, and eloquent. Her parents loved her very much.
When the daughter grew up, she spoke a verse and asked her parents:
'All swiftly flowing waters, the affairs of suffering and joy in the world, where do they originally come from? When will they come to rest?'
Her parents, upon hearing this, admired her extraordinary eloquence, but did not know what to say in reply to this verse.
The daughter wanted to understand this meaning but did not receive an answer, so she became greatly distressed and no longer ate or drank.

Her parents saw that their daughter was sorrowful and worried, so they were greatly alarmed. They immediately held a great assembly, invited brahmins and many wise elders, and the crowd gathered like clouds.

After the offerings were set out, in the midst of the assembly they arranged a small bed, and the daughter sat upon it. She again spoke the previous verse to ask the crowd, but the crowd remained silent and no one could answer.
The elder then filled a tray with seven treasures and proclaimed:
Whoever can answer will be given this.
At that time, there was a brahmin who was physically upright but had little wisdom. Greedy for the precious treasures, he said:
I can answer.
When the girl heard this, she spoke a verse to ask the brahmin, but he did not understand the meaning of the verse. He simply said:
This matter is completely nonexistent.
The girl then contemplated and attained the concentration of non-existence. She then exclaimed:
This true great teacher has benefited me greatly.
After the girl's life ended, she was reborn in the heaven of non-existence. After forty kalpas, when her heavenly lifespan was exhausted, she was reborn in this world.
At that time, the elder's daughter is now the old sow's body. Her heavenly blessings were exhausted and her past karma reached her, so she received the body of a pig in this world.
When this woman originally asked the question in verse, if she had met a wise teacher, she could have attained the Way;
although this woman practiced meditation, she lacked wisdom. When the reward for meditation ended, she fell back into the evil realms.
(16) In the past, there was a great king whose body suffered from a serious illness for twelve years without improvement. No great doctor could cure him.

At that time, in a small country on the border that belonged to the great king, there was a doctor who was good at treating illnesses. The king immediately summoned him to treat his own illness. In a short time, he was cured.
The king then thought of repaying the teacher's kindness. He repeatedly sent messengers to proclaim in that country:

This teacher cured the king's illness and should receive great merit. He should be rewarded with elephants, horses, carriages, cows, sheep, fields, houses, male and female servants, and various ornaments. All should be given to him.

The king of the small country respectfully received the order and prepared a house with a high hall and multiple stories for him. He provided the teacher's wife with clothing, food, jewelry, elephants, horses, cows, and sheep, all in abundance.
While the teacher was by the king's side, no one spoke to him. The teacher then thought:
I have made great efforts in treating the king's illness. I do not know if the king will reward me or not.
After several more days, the king gradually recovered. The teacher requested leave to return to his own country, and the king allowed it, providing him with a weak horse and worn-out riding gear.
The teacher greatly lamented:
I have made great efforts in treating the king's illness, but the king does not recognize my kindness and does not provide me with anything. He lets me leave empty-handed.
He lamented along the way, considering it a lasting grievance.
When he just arrived in his own country, he saw a herd of elephants and asked the elephant cubs:
Whose elephants are these?
The elephant cubs replied:
These are so-and-so's teacher's elephants.
He then asked the elephant trainer's son:
Where did your master get this elephant?
The elephant trainer's son replied:
Our master cured the king's illness and received it as a reward.
They continued on and saw a herd of horses. He asked the horse trainer's son:
Whose horses are these?
The horse trainer's son replied:
Our master's horses.
They went further and saw herds of cattle and sheep. He asked the herders:
Whose cattle and sheep are these?
The herders replied:
Our master's cattle and sheep.
They went further and saw his former house with lofty halls and multiple stories, unlike his original home. He asked the gatekeeper:
Whose house is this?
The gatekeeper replied:
This is our master's house.
He then entered the house and saw his wife with a radiant complexion and wearing jeweled garments. He wondered and asked:
Whose wife is this?
The attendant replied:
This is the wife of so-and-so.

From seeing the elephants and horses to entering the house, he knew that these were the rewards obtained from treating the king's illness, and he then regretted that he had not put more effort into treating the king's illness.

The analogy for blessings and virtues is that obstacles to blessings and virtues are like the king's illness. The doctor is analogous to the person who cultivates blessings and virtues. Treating the king's illness is analogous to the practitioner's ability to cultivate meritorious deeds.

The king's illness being cured is analogous to blessings and virtues already being accomplished. The king's proclamation to reward him with elephants, horses, and a house means that blessings accumulate here and rewards are accomplished there.
Those who hope for speed always suffer from slow responses.

It is like a person with little faith who sometimes performs meritorious deeds and then hopes for rewards day after day. When old age, illness, and death arrive, they say that there is naturally no good retribution. When the wholesome response of the intermediate state of existence in the heavens is fully received, it is like the doctor seeing the elephants and horses.

Riding this intermediate existence, they arrive at the heavenly palace and receive the birth existence there. Seeing the various adornments of the heavenly palace with their own eyes, they then know and regret that they did not do more in the past.
It is like that physician who, upon receiving the reward, regrets that he did not put more effort into treating the illness.

(17) In foreign countries, there was a time when evil rain fell. If it fell into rivers, lakes, wells, city ponds, and other bodies of water, people who drank this water would become insane and intoxicated for seven days before recovering.
At that time, there was a king with great wisdom and good discernment. When the evil rain clouds arose, the king knew it and covered a well to prevent the rain from entering.

At that time, the hundred officials and ministers drank the evil rain water, and the entire court became insane, taking off their clothes and sitting naked, with mud smeared on their heads in the king's hall. Only the king himself was not insane, wearing his usual clothes, a heavenly crown, and necklaces, sitting on his original seat.
All the ministers did not know they were insane, and instead called the king greatly insane, asking why he was the only one dressed like that.
The people all said to each other:
This is not a small matter, let us think about it together.
The king feared that the ministers wanted to rebel, so he became frightened himself and said to the ministers:
I have a good medicine that can cure this illness. Everyone wait a little, wait for me to take the medicine, and I will come out in a moment.

The king then entered the palace, took off his clothes, smeared mud on his face, and came out in a moment. All the ministers saw this and were greatly delighted, thinking it was the proper way, not knowing that he was insane himself.

After seven days, the ministers woke up and were greatly ashamed. They all put on their clothes and came to the court meeting. The king was still sitting naked as before. The ministers were all surprised and asked:
The king has always been very wise, why is he like this?
The king replied to the ministers:
My mind is always stable and unchanging. It is because you were insane that you thought I was insane. Therefore, it is like this, it is not my true mind.

The TathÄgata is also like this. Sentient beings always go mad from drinking the water of ignorance. If they hear the Great Sage always speaking of the non-arising and non-ceasing of all dharmas, the one characteristic and no characteristics, they will certainly consider the Great Sage's words to be mad talk.
Therefore, the TathÄgata follows sentient beings and presently speaks of the good and evil of all dharmas, the conditioned and the unconditioned.
(18) In a past life, the asura was once a poor man who lived near a river and always crossed the river to carry firewood.

At that time, the river water was deep and the current was swift. This man was often swept away by the water, and his body was also submerged and floated along with the current, barely escaping with difficulty.

At that time, there was a pratyekabuddha who appeared in the form of a monk and went to his house to beg for food. The poor man was delighted and immediately offered food. After the meal, he washed the water and placed the empty bowl in the sky and flew away.
The poor man saw this and made a vow:
I wish that in my next life, my body will be tall and large, and no deep water will reach my knees.

Because of this cause and condition, he obtained an extremely large body, and the four great oceans could not reach his knees. Standing in the great ocean, his body surpassed Mount Sumeru, and he reached down with his hand to observe the Heaven of the Thirty-three.
How much less could the countless eons of the Buddha's great vows and his Dharma body filling the void be doubted?
(19) In the past, there was a prince who was only seven years old. He entered a deep mountain to seek the Way of the Immortals. He had never known the duties of the officials of the court.
Later, when the king's life ended, there was no one suitable to be the king of the country. The ministers discussed together:
The immortal in the mountain is originally the prince. Moreover, he cultivates morality and virtue. Using him as the king, the myriad countries will rely on him.

The people of the country all went to the mountain, bowed to the immortal as their king, and welcomed him back to the country in a royal carriage, proclaiming to the kitchen officials to prepare exquisite food and delicacies to entertain the great king.
Because the king enjoyed the delicious food, he asked the kitchen official for all the other things one by one. The ministers all laughed and said to the king:

The duties of the hundred officials each have their own responsibilities. The kitchen official is responsible for food, the clothing official is responsible for clothing, and military affairs and the treasury each have their own offices. One cannot blame a single person for the delicious food.
This analogy illustrates that the various sÅ«tras each have their own teachings and one cannot blame a single sÅ«tra.

If it itself clarifies the true nature of all dharmas, the Abhidharma clarifies the existence of all dharmas, each with different characteristics, and explains them in terms of characteristics and non-characteristics.
20 (20) Deer Park In the past, there were five hundred herds of deer in this forest. The king of the deer was one who was a bodhisattva and the other was a real deer king.

At that time, a king went out of the city to hunt. Seeing this herd of deer, he led his troops to surround them. The two deer kings together devised a plan and both went to the human king, kneeling for a long time and said to the human king:

Now in the king's territory, we will accept the slaughter. If the king kills all the deer at one time, we will not be able to eat them all in time and they may go bad. We wish to send two deer every day to provide food for the king. The rest will be sent in order every day, not daring to be negligent.
We ask that the king allow us to extend our lives a little. Is this not the grace of the great king?
Then the human king listened to what they said and released them, opening the encirclement.
From then on, the two deer kings took turns and sent two deer every day to the king's kitchen.
After several more days, there was a pregnant doe whose turn it was to die. That doe went to the king and asked to wait until after giving birth. The king replied:
The other deer have not yet taken their turn. Who will replace you?
That doe then went to the king of the bodhisattva deer and said to the bodhisattva:
My king is not kind and does not act with reason. I now come to take refuge. Please act with reason for me.
The bodhisattva deer king took pity on her and went to the kitchen of the human king himself. The cook reported to the king, saying:
The king of the deer came to the kitchen himself, seeking to replace that pregnant doe.
The king then found it strange and rare, and told the cook:
Bring that king of deer here.
Then the king of deer went to the human king and extensively explained his intention to the king. The human king then gave rise to faith.
Even birds and beasts still cultivate virtue, how much more so humans?

He ordered that within the entire country, hunting and killing would be permanently prohibited, and this forest would be permanently donated to the herd of deer. From then on, it became known as the Deer Park.

(21) In the past, there was a householder whose wife became pregnant. He invited the Buddha to his home for offerings. After the offerings were completed, he wanted the Tathagata to predict the gender of the child his wife would give birth to.
The Buddha said:
Later, she will give birth to a son who will be upright and handsome. When he grows up, he will enjoy heavenly bliss among humans, and later he will attain the path of arhatship.

When the householder heard this, he doubted and did not believe it. Later, he again invited the six masters for offerings, and again asked them to predict [the gender of the child]. The householder said to the six masters:
Previously, I had Gautama Shakra predict it, and he said that I will give birth to a son. I don't know if it's true or not.
The six masters said:
You will give birth to a daughter.
Those six masters hated the Buddha's teachings and wanted to go against them. They thought to themselves:
If she gives birth to a boy, that householder will abandon me and serve Gautama.
So he spoke a deceptive word:
Householder!

Your wife will give birth to a boy, but after the boy is born there will be a great misfortune, and the family and relatives will be exterminated for seven generations. Because of the inauspiciousness, I previously spoke falsely that it is a girl.
When the householder heard this, he was frightened and did not know what to do.
Those six masters then said to the householder:
If you want good fortune, you must only get rid of it.
The six masters then pressed the householder's wife's abdomen, pressing it to cause it to fall out.
The pressing did not stop, and the householder's wife eventually died, but the child did not die, because of the blessings from her past lives.

The householder then abandoned his wife in the place for the dead, piled up a large amount of firewood and burned her. As the flames grew intense, the Buddha then went there with his disciples to observe. The body of the householder's wife was destroyed, and they saw her son sitting on a lotus flower, upright and extremely handsome with a complexion like snow.
The Buddha ordered JÄ«vaka:
Take this child and come.
JÄ«vaka then took him and brought him back to the original householder. The householder then raised him.

By the time he was sixteen years old, his talent and beauty surpassed that of others. He then extensively prepared many delicious foods and invited the six masters. After the six masters sat down, before long he lost his composure and laughed. The man asked:
Why are you laughing?
The six masters then replied:
We saw a mountain fifty thousand li away, under the mountain there was water, and a monkey fell into the water. This is why we laughed.

The child knew it was false, so he filled his bowl with various delicious soups and covered them with rice, having someone carry it to him. In the bowls of the others, he put rice on the bottom and soup on top.
Everyone ate, but the six masters alone became angry and did not eat.
The host asked:
Why don't you eat?
The six masters replied:
Without soup, how can I eat?
The host said:
Your eyes can see five thousand miles, and you see a monkey falling into the water, but why don't you see the soup under the rice?
Thereupon, the six masters became very angry, did not eat in the end, and returned, going straight to ÅšrÄ«gupta to explain in detail.
His sister became ÅšrÄ«gupta's wife. When ÅšrÄ«gupta heard about it, he also became angry and told the six masters:
Gautama is their teacher, and I am the great teacher. I invite him to come and humiliate him.
Therefore, he made a pit of fire and poisoned rice.
This analogy is extremely extensive and cannot be listed one by one, so only the essentials are briefly mentioned.
(22) In the past, a Daoist went to a Brahmin's house to beg for food. The Brahmin had his wife bring out food to give to him. The wife stood in front.
The wife was upright, and the Daoist's mind gave rise to change upon seeing her. He said to the Brahmin:
The faults of indulging in desires have come out.
The Brahmin did not understand and asked:
What are the faults of indulging in desires that have come out?
The Daoist then embraced the wife and kissed her, and said to the Brahmin:
This is indulging in desires.
The Brahmin became very angry and hit the Daoist with a stick once. The Daoist said again:
This is the fault.
He wanted to hit again, but the Daoist ran out the door and looked back to say to the Brahmin:
This is coming out.
It is like a person who cannot deeply understand the meaning of the teachings and must rely on pointing to things in order to awaken to them.
(23) In the past, there was a farmer who temporarily went to the capital city. He saw someone being whipped and having hot horse dung applied to his back. He asked:
Why is it like this?
That person replied:
It causes the wounds to heal quickly without scarring.
The farmer secretly kept this in mind. Later, when he returned home, he told his family:
When I went to the capital, I gained great wisdom.
Later, the family members asked:
What kind of wisdom did you gain?
He then called the servant and said:
Bring the whip and give me two hundred lashes.
The servant feared disobeying the master and immediately gave him two hundred lashes, causing blood to flow and cover his back. He then told the servant:
Take some hot horse dung and apply it to me. It will cause it to heal quickly without scarring.
He told the family members:
Do you know this?
This is wisdom.

This analogy is for those who have received precepts from a bright teacher, but upon seeing others receiving precepts, they abandon their original precepts and become laypeople again, thus destroying their Dharma body.
It is like receiving two hundred lashes, with blood covering their backs, and then seeking to receive [precepts] again, like smearing horse dung.

(24) In a foreign country, there was a dragon-taming master who filled a military kettle with water and went to the dragon pond, single-mindedly reciting a mantra to the dragon. The dragon immediately saw a great fire rising from the bottom of the pond, burning the entire pond.

The dragon, frightened by the fire, raised its head to look at the mountains, but saw the great fire burning all the mountains and marshes. Looking up at the mountain peak, there was nowhere to stay, as everything was hot. The only place to escape was in the water in the military kettle, so it extinguished the fire and transformed its body into a tiny form to enter the water in the kettle.

The dragon pond is a metaphor for the desire realm, the mountains and marshes that are hoped for are a metaphor for the form realm, looking at the mountain peak is a metaphor for the formless realm, the dragon-taming master is a metaphor for the bodhisattva, the slow army water is a metaphor for nirvana, the mantra is a metaphor for skillful means, the great fire burning is a metaphor for manifesting impermanence, the dragon's large body is a metaphor for arrogance, and making a small form is a metaphor for humility.

It is said that the bodhisattva manifests the burning of the kalpa, with the desire and form realms completely burning, the great fire of impermanence terrifying sentient beings, causing them to remove arrogance and be humble, and only then does he completely enter nirvana.
(25) In the past, from a long time ago in a foreign country, there was once a stone by the side of a road, which was trampled by carts and horses, slightly damaged.
At that time, there were people in the world who disliked it obstructing the road and wanted to remove it, so they immediately broke it.
He saw a poisonous snake emerge from the rock, gaining wind it grew huge, in an instant its body filled the entire JambudvÄ«pa.
In one day it devoured all the sentient beings and creatures in JambudvÄ«pa, then died.

This is the swift retribution of evil karma, how much more so for the bodhisattva who originally was an ordinary person, accumulating merit and virtue for countless eons, just from arousing the intention he attained Buddhahood, expounded the Dharma to liberate people and then entered parinirvÄá¹‡a, is this benefit not swift enough to be amazing?
(26) In the past there was a snake whose head and tail argued with each other. The head said to the tail:
I should be the great one.
The tail said to the head:
I should also be the great one.
The head said:
I have ears that can hear, eyes that can see, and a mouth that can eat. When walking, I am at the very front, therefore I can be the great one;
You do not have these skills, you should not be the great one.
The tail said:

I let you go, so you can go. If I were to wrap my body around the tree three times for three days without stopping, my head would not be able to go out to seek food, and I would be on the verge of starving to death.
The head said to the tail:
You can let it go and allow it to be the leader.
When the tail heard these words, it immediately let go.
It further said to the tail:
Since you are the leader, I allow you to go in front.
The tail went in front, but after only a few steps, it fell into a pit of fire and died.

This parable illustrates that in the Sangha, there may be a wise and virtuous elder who is able to decide on the Vinaya, but there are those below who are unwilling to comply. The elder is unable to control them, so he says:
If you want to do so, it is up to you.
The matter is not accomplished, and they all fall into non-dharma, like the snake falling into the pit of fire.

27 (27) In the past, there was a bird catcher who set a net on a marsh, with the food that birds like placed in it. Many birds flocked to compete for the food, and the bird catcher pulled up the net, and all the birds fell into the net.
At that time, there was a large bird with great strength. It lifted the net with all the birds and flew away. The bird catcher followed its shadow.
Someone said to the bird catcher:
The birds fly in the sky, and you walk after them. How foolish!
The bird catcher replied:
Do not say this. Those birds will seek a place to roost at dusk. They will go in different directions. This is how they will fall.

The man still followed without stopping. As the day turned to dusk, he looked up and saw the many birds flying and struggling, wanting to go east or west, hoping for a long forest or rushing to a pond. They did not stop and soon fell. The bird catcher finally caught them one by one and killed them.

The bird catcher is like PÄpÄ«yÄn, the spread net is like the afflictions, carrying the net and flying is like a person who has not yet left the afflictions and wants to seek liberation, stopping at dusk is like a person who becomes lazy and no longer makes progress, seeking different roosts is like giving rise to the sixty-two views and always contradicting each other, the bird falling to the ground is like a person receiving an evil retribution and falling into hell.
This clarifies that the dust and dirt of the afflictions are the net of MÄra.
(28) In the past when the Buddha was in the world, there were five hundred strong men who all became Å›ramaá¹‡as and sat together in meditation and recitation.
There was a cunning thief who completely robbed the Å›ramaá¹‡as of their robes and alms bowls, leaving only their saá¹ƒghÄá¹­Ä« robes.
After the thief left, the Å›ramaá¹‡as lightly put on their saá¹ƒghÄá¹­Ä« robes and went together to where the Buddha was. They fully explained this matter. The Buddha said to the Å›ramaá¹‡as:
Why didn't you shout loudly?
The Å›ramaá¹‡as replied:
The Buddha has not allowed it, so we dare not call out.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
If you dare not call out, the thieves will strip you of your robes every day. Who can always provide them?
From today onwards, I allow you to shout loudly when you see thieves coming, to grab sticks, bricks, and stones to frighten them away, but do not sincerely harm them.
What people value most are their bodies, lives, and wealth. These three things are not to be begrudged and should not be taken lightly.

What is not to be begrudged is that they are impermanent, decaying, and without solidity. The foolish and deluded begrudge them, considering them their own possessions. Greedily clinging to them and begrudging them creates unwholesome causes and conditions, and one later falls into evil realms. Therefore, they are not to be begrudged.

What should not be taken lightly is that because one has a body, one encounters sages. Bowing, kneeling, bending one's fists, and welcoming and paying respects, one later attains a vajra-jewel body that cannot be destroyed. Therefore, it is said that it should not be taken lightly.

As for life not being worth cherishing, people kill, steal, and commit adultery for the sake of life, verbally commit the four offenses, and mentally give rise to greed, anger, and wrong views, and later fall into hell. Therefore, it is said to be not worth cherishing.

As for it also not being light, because there is life, one encounters sages and virtuous ones, hears the Dharma and its profound meaning, enters the spirit and practices for the rest of one's life, and later attains a precious life that is immeasurable and endless. Therefore, it is said to also not be light.

As for wealth not being worth cherishing, wealth is a share of the five families. If thieves, water, fire, the county government, or bad children suddenly arrive, it will all be gone in a day. Therefore, it is said to not be worth cherishing.

As for it not being light, encountering a good field of blessings and using it for giving, making various offerings without sparing anything, later attaining precious wealth and the four great treasuries, providing for the poor and needy, and obtaining inexhaustible resources, therefore it is said to not be light.
All who cultivate merit and virtue should aim to seek the attainment of Buddhahood, and should not just seek the rewards of the human and heavenly realms.
Why is this?

It is like planting grains just seeking the fruit, although the fruit is not yet ripe, the stems, nodes, and leaves are naturally obtained. Giving and making merit is also like this, the intention is just seeking the attainment of the path of nirvana of the Buddha, although the path is not yet attained, the pleasures of the human and heavenly realms, the golden wheel sage king, Åšakra, and BrahmÄ naturally arrive all at once, it is also like planting grains not expecting the stems, nodes, and leaves to be naturally obtained.
This is why one should not just seek the pleasures of the rewards of the human and heavenly realms.

(29) In the past, in India, there was a dwelling place with one hundred thousand Å›ramaá¹‡as, more than fifty thousand of whom had attained arhatship, with the six supernatural powers, clear insight, and all defilements exhausted, while the remaining fifty thousand either had attained the three lower paths or had not yet attained them.
There was an elder who wished to seek the blessings and pleasures of humans and gods, and came to the temple to provide food and make offerings to the Sangha.

At that time, there was an elder who had attained the six supernatural powers and was a great arhat. He was extremely old, with white hair and missing teeth, and his body was withered. He was the leader among the hundred thousand people.
After the elder had finished making the vow and the meal was over, he washed his hands and said to the elder:
Lay donor!
Now your offering will only bring about great misfortune.
At that time, those in the assembly who had not yet attained the Way all thought:
The elder is old, so he speaks these crazy words.
The elder replied:
The facts are indeed so, it is not crazy talk.
The people asked:
This person has planted blessings, how can he incur misfortune?
The elder replied:
You recognize one but not the other.

This person plants blessings and again receives happiness among humans and gods, but while receiving happiness, they greatly give rise to arrogance and consider themselves sufficient, not seeking liberation. Seeing the Buddha, they do not revere him; seeing the sutras, they do not read them; seeing monks, they have no reverent mind. Careless and unrestrained, once their blessings are exhausted, they will fall into evil paths for immeasurable asamkhyeya kalpas. After their sins are finished, they will then emerge. The reason they can plant great sins is because they receive the great retribution of worldly existence.
If one intends to take the path to sagehood and do these blessings, then when one receives retribution later, one will never receive this retribution.

In the past, in India, there were two poor people who lived frugally and always sold yogurt to make a living. The two people each carried a yogurt jar on their heads and went to the market to sell it.
At that time, it was raining and the roads were muddy. One person was wise and thought to himself:
Today it is raining mud and the road is difficult to travel. If I fall over, the jar will break and I will lose everything. Now I have taken out the butter. If I fall over, the loss will be minimal.

One person with little wisdom held the jar and went to the market. On the way, the mud was slippery and the two fell together. One person was sorrowful, wept, rolled on the ground, and lay there. The other person had no sorrowful expression at all and did not feel regret.
Someone asked:

The two of you broke the yogurt jars and lost the same amount. There is no difference between you. Why is one person alone sorrowful, weeping, and regretful, while the other is calm and has no expression of regret at all?
One person answered:
The yogurt I was carrying has not yet turned into butter. Today the jar broke and I lost everything. That is why I am sorrowful and cannot control myself.
The other person answered:
The yogurt I was carrying has already turned into butter. Now although the jar broke, the loss is minimal. That is why I am calm and have nothing to regret.
The jar is a metaphor for the body, and the ghee is a metaphor for wealth.
There are people who are stingy and greedy for wealth, greedy for present benefits, not thinking of impermanence, and suddenly their physical jar is destroyed and their wealth is lost.
It is like that person forgetting the ghee and yogurt, regretting and blaming themselves without avail.
There are people who deeply believe in the karmic retribution of the next world, and use all their wealth to give in charity, and although their physical jar is destroyed, they lose very little.
It is also like that person whose ghee jar is destroyed, but they lose very little, and their mind is at ease without any regret.
(31) In the past, there were 500 merchants who sailed the ocean in search of treasures. They encountered a makara fish that emerged, opened its mouth, and wanted to eat the creatures.
At that time, there was little wind and the ship went like an arrow. The leader of the merchants said to the people:
The ship is going too fast, lower the sails and sink.
They immediately did as he said, lowered the sails and sank, but the ship went even faster and could not be stopped.
The leader of the caravan asked the man on the tower:
What do you see?
I see two suns rising above, white mountains below, and a black mountain in between.
The leader of the caravan was startled and said:
This is a huge fish. What should we do?
We are now in a difficult situation, entering the belly of this fish with no hope of survival. You should each seek help from your own beliefs with single-minded focus.

Then the people each turned to their own beliefs, single-mindedly taking refuge to escape this calamity. The more fervently they sought, the faster the boat went, soon stopping as it was about to enter the fish's mouth.
Then the leader of the caravan told the people:
I have a great deity named Buddha. You should all abandon your previous beliefs and single-mindedly chant his name.
At that time, the five hundred people together shouted Namo Buddha. The fish heard the name Buddha and thought to itself:
Today, the world has a Buddha again. How can I bear to harm sentient beings?
As soon as he had this thought, he immediately closed his mouth, and the water flowed back far into the fish's mouth. The five hundred merchants were all released.

This fish had previously been a monk in a past life, but due to his offenses, he received the body of a fish. Having heard the Buddha's name, he immediately remembered his past lives, and therefore had wholesome thoughts and a good mind arose.

This clarifies that the five hundred merchants, merely single-mindedly thinking of the Buddha and briefly chanting his name, were immediately released from the calamity of being swallowed by the whale. How much more so for those who uphold the samÄdhi of mindfulness of the Buddha, where heavy offenses become light and light ones are extinguished. Such responses are not yet considered many.

34. All plants in the world can be used as medicine, it's just that those who are not good at distinguishing do not know it.

There was only one harÄ«takÄ«, which was placed on one side alone, not weeping, and said to itself:

(35) In the past, there was a butcher who went to King Ajatashatru and asked for a wish.

This is only knowing past lives, not supernormal powers or wisdom.

(36) In the past, there was a king who deeply understood karma and its fruits, and believed in the law of cause and effect. He always enjoyed giving and never went against people's wishes. His reputation flowed to the four directions and was known everywhere.

He replied to me:

He then said to me:

Then the king, hearing the brÄhman's words, immediately shed tears, moved his seat, and said to the former king:

Thereupon, he took back what he had taken and returned to his own country. The former king regained his position and ruled as before.

This illustrates that when the Bodhisattva was still an ordinary person, his conduct and virtues were like this. If one writes and keeps this sÅ«tra with utmost sincerity, neither gods nor evil people will be able to take advantage.
There are two kinds of thieves: first, thieves with physical strength.
Second, thieves with skillful means.

Thieves with physical strength dig through walls with their own hands, or make the shape of a lion's head or a lotus flower, enter a house to take things, but do not take everything. They leave a little bit, wanting the owner to be able to make a living and have people praise them as good thieves.

He changed back into his own clothes and went with the others to the house where the goods had been lost. When the group saw the hole in the wall made by the thief, they all said, This is a skillful thief.
At that time, there was a thief who was an expert in disguise, also among them. He said,
This is not a skillful thief. He used a lot of effort and obtained only a little. How can that be skillful?
Only if one obtains a lot of goods without using any effort, that is skillful.
At that time, the thief who used force secretly took this to heart. He waited until the others had left and then asked the expert in disguise,
What is a thief who uses skillful means?
He replied,
If you want to know, just follow me. In a month or so, I will let you see.
Then the thief who used skillful means, disguised as a subtle brahmin, went to the house of a very wealthy elder and said to the elder,

At that time, the elder asked for the price of a robe and immediately replied:

Before he could get it, he went again and said:

The elder replied:

In this way, up to three times, he wrote a letter to the officials, saying:

The thief then took the elder's enemy as a witness. At that time, the officials arrested the witness and the elder, and asked the witness:

The witness replied:
It is true.
The officials then ordered the elder to pay the gold to the brahmin. The thief used skillful means without physical strength to obtain a great deal of wealth. The same is true for rejoicing.

In the past, there was a great Brahma King named Bhagavat. Due to the causes and conditions of planting the causes for a long life in his previous lives, his lifespan lasted for the lifespans of seventy-two Brahma Heaven people, and because his lifespan was not exhausted, he used this lifespan to give rise to wrong views and considered himself to be eternal.
He further thought:
I have attained self-mastery. From now on, no one will be able to falsely see me. If I allow them to come, they will see me, but if I do not allow it, they will stop.

The Buddha used his spiritual mind and the eyes of the Way to illuminate and examine his mind. Together with Shariputra, Maudgalyayana, and the other four great disciples, he flew up into the air and sat on top of his head. Shariputra was on the right, Maudgalyayana was on the left, Mahakasyapa was in front, and Mahakatyayana was in the back. He told the Brahma King:
You consider yourself to be eternal and to have self-mastery. How can I now sit on top of your head?
He further asked:
What have you seen that you consider yourself to be eternally free?
The Brahma King replied:
In my Brahma Heaven, seventy-two people have died in succession, but I have not.
Furthermore, three greatly meritorious heavenly beings have passed away, but I have not.
For this reason, I consider myself to be eternal.
The Buddha told the Brahma King:
I am a person of omniscience. I see when you were born and when you will die, as well as all dharmas without error. Do not foolishly delude yourself into thinking you are eternal.
This Brahma King also knew his past lives. Did he know for certain when he was about to become a Buddha?
He then said to the Buddha:
The Buddha knows the causes and conditions of my past life, by which I obtained this lifespan.
The Buddha told the Brahma King:

In the past, you were a sage with the five supernatural powers. You saw many people on a boat in the ocean, and a violent storm suddenly arose with waves as high as the sky. With your supernatural powers, you rescued the people and brought them to shore, saving them from the danger of death. This is the first cause.

Again, in the past, you were a minister of a great country. There was a village that committed a crime against the king. The king became very angry and wanted to exterminate the entire village. You felt compassion for them and exhausted your family's wealth to provide a way out, saving them from destruction. This is the second cause.
Because of these two causes, you have attained this long life. However, after another thirty-six eons, your life will come to an end.
When Brahma Heaven King heard the Buddha's words, faith arose in him. He single-mindedly contemplated and attained the path of non-returner.
